thread.title: Argos receiver Kevin Elliott thankful to team for allowing him to attend grandmother's funeral
thread.title_full: Argos receiver Kevin Elliott thankful to team for allowing him to attend grandmother's funeral

title: Argos receiver Kevin Elliott thankful to team for allowing him to attend grandmother's funeral
text:
Argos coach Scott Milanovich backing QB Trevor Harris 
For those who have played the game and remain involved in the game, football is often referred to as the ultimate team sport. 
No matter what kind of elite talent lines up on either side of the ball, you’re only as good as the player next to you. 
In many ways, it’s an extension of a family, a unique brotherhood that bonds and threatens to disrupt team chemistry when an individual is allowed to do his own thing. 
Kevin Elliott has a greater appreciation for his Argonauts teammates, even though not many had realized what they did to support Elliott during his time of need. 
A week ago in Hamilton, Elliott wasn’t with the Double Blue as they played a home game in Hamilton against Calgary. 
A few days earlier, he was at practice oozing that care-free spirit and flashing that big smile that has endeared Elliott to so many in his first season in the CFL. 
He then disappeared. 
Elliott’s maternal grandmother, Madear, had passed away. 
No one knew anything about Elliott’s personal situation until he approached head coach Scott Milanovich. 
“I have a lot of respect for coach Milanovich,’’ said Elliott, who is back with the team and will return to the field this Friday night when the Boatmen play their fourth home game on the road, back in The Hammer to take on the Montreal Alouettes. 
“Before I could even finish my story, he told me to go home, that family is first. 
“These guys here are my family, but I’m pretty sure they understood why I wanted to go home. I really appreciate them for understanding that.” 
Elliott says his beloved grandmother was feisty and combative, living life to its fullest until it was time. 
“She never wanted to sit down,’’ said Elliott of his grandmother, whom Elliott said was a victim of old age. 
“No one could ever tell her what to do. She was one of those stubborn individuals who never wanted to give up until it was time to go.” 
Elliott knew of his grandmother’s fate, but waited until the final funeral arrangements were made before approaching Milanovich. 
It just so happened the funeral coincided on the same day the Argos were to play the Calgary Stampeders. 
Elliott flew to Mississippi, stood by his mom to offer support and reconnected with family members he hasn’t seen in a while. 
“I don’t think my teammates know what they did for me,’’ said Elliott. “They kept my spirits up and gave me a chance to keep my mind off things.” 
Elliott says his grandmother wasn’t much of a sports fan, seldom attending any of his games in person. 
“But she’d call every week telling me: ‘I’m proud of you baby, I love you, keep doing your thing.’ She actually made me a quilt I carry with me every city I go to and I’ve got it in my house right now. 
“I just hold on to that quilt because it’s a quilt full of her love. When I wrap myself in it at night, it’s all good.” 
The Argos weren’t that good against Calgary, trailing 17-0 at halftime and never really threatening the defending Grey Cup champions. 
Having Elliott back in the lineup helps, but the biggest key with this Argos franchise has been turnovers. 
Elliott is aware of the team’s standings and the possibility of winning the East, which would require Toronto winning all three of its remaining games and having Hamilton lose two of its three. 
All three of Toronto’s opponents — Montreal, B.C. and Winnipeg — have losing records, each team having already lost to the Argos. 
“We’re basically approaching these games as though we need to win them all to make it to the playoffs,’’ said Elliott of his 9-6 Argos, who assured themselves of a post-season berth last weekend following losses by the Lions and Als. 
“We realize we’ve clinched a playoff berth, but we’re not relaxing. 
“We’re treating these games like we need to get in. Honestly, we’re trying to get that playoff bye and we still have a chance at it.” 

HURTING ALL OVER 
The Toronto Argonauts’ offensive line has taken a beating this year, bodies dropping when injuries hit, players switching from one side to another. 
After playing 15 games, Tyler Holmes and Greg Van Roten have emerged as the only linemen to start each game for the Double Blue. 
Holmes may emerge as the lone survivor, at least heading into Friday night’s game against the Montreal Alouettes, a team whose strength is on defence with its line setting the tone. 
During his availability on Wednesday, Argos head coach Scott Milanovich said Van Roten, who has started at centre, guard and tackle, is questionable for Friday. 
A day earlier, Van Roten and defensive tackle Euclid Cummings got into a fight during practice. 
Milanovich would also say that veteran Wayne Smith is down. 
“We’ll have to lean on guys who haven’t played much,’’ said Milanovich. 
The Argos have recently added to their practice roster by bringing in linemen the team has liked, but has been unable to play because of the ratio. 
Van Roten is an American, allowing the Argos to replace an import with an import. 
Canadian H-back Alexandre Dupuis (foot) seems ready to return. 
Milanovich also confirmed American punter Jake Rogers will make his CFL debut Friday night. 
If one were to include receiver Dave Stala, Rogers brings to nine the amount of kickers the Scullers have signed this season. 
Stala wasn’t acquired to punt, but he has been forced into duties following injuries to Swayze Waters. Sponsored Links
